discourse_list.title: [Discussion] Establishing Minimum Interest Rates Guidelines for MIP borrowers

content.content: I would like us to set guidelines for a minimum on acceptable rates in applications, say US treasury yields+0.5%. Applicants going below this would need to provide strong justification upfront for going below this rate. This would primarily be a timesaving measure, to keep the forums cleaner and keep focus on credible applicants. This will become more important if we start getting more applicants and the protocol grows. I would like feedback, both on the concept and and specific numbers.

I would say this probably oversimplifies things.  I’m all for optimizing returns but you also want to diversify.  Treasury rates don’t always stay the same.  They can go back to 0 and all of a sudden, you might wish some of those projects you rejected because of this rule had been onboarded.  What you want is to have a good mix of levers to pull so you can react when the environment changes and to do that you need to keep onboarding quality providers of different types of collateral.

The best way to counteract treasury yields going to 0 is to buy treasuries at current rates. Even if we knew for a fact that treasury yields were going to 0 in six months, I don’t see how that would justify onboarding a provider offering lower yields right now. Especially considering that the most likely reason treasuries would go to 0 is a recession, which would make the risk-adjusted returns of alternative collateral even worse.

If treasury yields go to 0, the future value of held bonds could be largely captured immediately and reallocated elsewhere if desired.  I think that’s a huge assumption to make that all collateral types that have lower returns now will always have lower returns later even if there was a recession.  Certainly treasuries will always be safer but as we have seen, they can remain at 0 well after a recovery is underway.

You probably have to think about long-term CoC of Maker (i.e. the liability side). What does Maker have to “pay” for DAI demand (DSR+) ? (as you cannot take on any collateral unless there is a long-term demand for the DAI that being issued on the back this collateral). Instinctively - and I don’t have a lot science to back this instinct up (yet…) - I continue to like the idea of using the common central bank long-term inflation target of 2% as a general starting point and then adjust for global market conditions (inflationary/deflationary), demand for DAI in market and then ultimately add an individual collateral risk and duration premium/consideration. At anyrate, I would definitely not recommend setting asset-side interest rate guidelines that are disconnected from the actual liability side cost. It is quite a dangerous path. A lot of Makers market power sit in this balance sheet dynamics - very important to respect it.

In addition to the concerns that are presented here, it is important to note that Maker community should watch out for hidden fees baked into the comparable yield estimates. For example, Maker is currently considering solar finance deals in which the super-low yields that are being presented as comps are hiding “dealer fees” and other middleman overhead that is often charged in these sorts of transactions – including by companies started by those who are proposing these projects:    reddit   r/solar - Are we overreacting to solar loan model / dealer fees? 10 votes and 52 comments so far on Reddit      That being said – from what I can tell, the first RWA deal, in partnership with SocGen, was done at a 0% yield, with unanimous approval from the community? It seems that this may have set a precedent for these proposals, and biased the conversation toward “super safe cash-like instruments” rather than a healthy mix of risk and reward which would compel projects with more attractive yield to come forward. Having a well-defined policy on both risk profile and yield would be great.

Let’s not argue against deals that establish capabilities and relationships by pointing to other possible future deals with better yields. That sounds like the perfect attitude to derail any progress.

I think deals with the same risk profile as the SocGen deal were in the same ballpark range of yield, as it was backed by quasi-sovereign institutions. As a low-risk, low-yield deal, it seems like a great option — and, as you say, a great way to add capabilities and relationships to the ecosystem. The question is whether this is the risk/yield profile that the community is looking for — and also, if the community is willing to give up yield, potentially on the scale of tens of millions of dollars, for future capability- and relationship-building exercises. The proposals which have troubled the participants in this thread share a theme of presenting themselves in a similar manner. It also seems that there is a divergence of opinion among members of the community as to whether they will accept yield discounts for ESG / climate-related offerings. The ongoing Clean Money discussion speaks for itself. Having a consistent policy, openly stated, surrounding these issues would be helpful. For example, more high-profile TradFi participants might bring Maker more capabilities-building transactions such as the SocGen deal if they knew there was a specific policy to support them.

I don’t know what the right parameters are, but it’s clear we are suffering reputational damage by people going to large borrowers and telling them low-yield, risky loans are desired. Then a bunch of disrespectful replies clog the thread because the community is (understandably) worried. That’s just bad for everyone. So I agree a specific yield isn’t a good filter. But maybe if it’s below a given benchmark, there should be extra justification. Maybe it makes sense and maybe not. But right now we’re making ourselves look really bad by someone telling these borrowers we want to take on more risk for less pay, and then the ensuing responses on the threads.

Note that Clean Money is itself an attempt at going towards an openly-stated, consistent policy. As you can see the discussion is still very much ongoing despite a successful vote. This clearly points towards the necessity of being biased towards action – and I obviously don’t mean towards action that leads to systemic risk for Maker, but action that leads to measured&diversified risk, with the expectation that some of those risks will pan out. If there’s one mindset that’s needed at the moment, it is that of being ready to say “yes” to multiple things in parallel. Waiting for total consensus, waiting for better deals, making reasonable borrowers wait for no fundamental reason – this should be frightening for anyone who cares about Maker. The machine needs to keep moving.

I agree that inaction is a problem, which is why I want to set a clear minimum guideline for borrowers so they aren’t having to repeatedly change/resubmit proposals. It would speed up the process if borrowers know upfront that their 1% interest solar panel loan request is not going to be accepted. The current system is biased towards inaction because loan standards are unclear and the only way to get a definite answer is to submit an application and wait for the community to respond.
